segments.text: On both sides?
OK. All right.
Here we go.
This is an interview with Thomas Beltran by Diana Elizondo on November the 12th, 1989, at his home in 4603 Windlock in San Antonio, Texas, about Vietnam.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes.
Right.
To begin with, can you just tell me about your background, like when you were born, where did you grow up?
I was born in 1946, and I grew up on the east side of San Antonio.
Okay, and how was that like?
Tell me about your family.
Mainly I was raised by my grandparents because my parents were divorced when I was about six years old.
And...
My grandfather was mainly my role model.
How about your schooling?
What did you think about school?
I liked school, and I wanted to go to college and all that stuff.
But my mother being a single parent, and I had an adopted brother, and she had to provide for both of us.
So I didn't want to be a burden on her anymore than necessary.
So after high school, I started working in a wood shop, carpentry work.
When was this, what year?
And Vietnam had just started.
I did want to work longer, but then I got my draft notice that I was going to be drafted into the Army.
So I didn't want to go into the Army because all my grandfather and my uncles and my father had been in the Army.
And if I was going to go overseas and fight, I wanted to be under the best conditions in my favor, so I decided to join the Marine Corps.
So you mean like if you were with the Marines, what, that you'd be better protected or learn things better?
Yeah, I felt I'd have more confidence and better training in the Marines.
What scared you about the Army?
I mean, what did it seem?
To me, the Army kind of lacked a certain discipline.
They didn't have what I would call a real...
strict discipline or coerciveness, working together kind of thing.
And you found that in the Marines?
Yes.
How did you first hear about the Marines and get that impression from them?
Well, I used to, when I was a kid I used to read a lot of war comics and stuff like that.
And that's where I got most of it from, comic books.
Okay, so when did you first hear about Vietnam?
Right after Kennedy was assassinated, and it was still kind of in the background, but Kennedy kept trying to get across to us that we had to stop communism as far away from our shores as possible.
And that's why he was sending, at first they started sending advisors to Vietnam.
That's when I first heard about it.
Did you ever, when you were working, did you ever really want to go over and fight?
I mean, did you think, hey, I'd like to do that, or?

Well, it was like a fascination at first, you know, because my, like I said, my grandfather, he was in World War I, and then my uncles were in World War II, and then my younger relatives were in Korea.
So I figured it was Vietnam was my turn.
Okay.
And at this time when you were called, were you married yet?
Or how were you living?
Were you still living with your mom then?
Well, I was living with my mother when I got my draft notice.
And I went ahead and joined the Marines and went to boot camp.
And then when I was home on my 30 days leave, I got married.
OK. And why did you get married?
Well, I just needed something to come home to.
And I was really in love with your aunt.
How did she feel about when she found out that you were drafted?
Well, she didn't like it.
And she was worried about it, but I guess
It's just a part of life a man has to go through.
In those days it was.
And your mom, how did she feel about it?
She was really practically hysterical, crying.
She wrote to our congressman trying to get me out of going.
She was really hysterical to me.
Okay.
So when were you actually drafted, and was it by the lottery system, or was it... No, I wasn't drafted.
I went ahead and volunteered in the Marines.
Okay.
And when you did, how long would your tour of duty be?
In Vietnam, it was 13 months.
13 months.
Okay.
Could you tell me about, like, your... about...
your training, like what did they teach you in boot camp?
Was there like counter-insurgency tactics or what did you concentrate on?
Well, basically we started off with hand-to-hand combat in boot camp and then marksmanship, how to use, shoot real good and the basics, map reading so you know where you were at all the time.
All the basic military skills, what you learned
And then when you make it through boot camp, then they test you and you get your specialized training.
Which is what?
Your military occupational status.
Like if you're mechanically inclined, they'll send you to either aviation school or armored vehicles, things mechanical.
And then if you...
or into electronics and stuff.
They didn't send you either to radar or radio school or whatever.
So what was your area of specialization?
I went into armored personnel carriers because I was mechanically inclined.
What does that mean?
Well, these were amphibious vehicles that we used to go on river patrols and to make beach landings off ships.
We would drive off a ship into the
water and make beach landings.
So you were in charge of making sure that those machines worked?
Yeah.
Okay.
Does that mean that you would be engaged in combat?
Do you know what I mean?
Yes.
When I was in Vietnam, we were what was called, used as a blocking force.
The infantry would sweep through an area of the country, and we would be hidden in the jungle.
And whatever enemy they pushed towards us, we'd be like a wall there to stop them.
Okay.
With our firepower.
All right.
And during your training, did you notice any difference or any, like, racism?
Like, were there just white officers and Hispanic, you know, units?
Or was it integration of troops, you know, blacks and whites and everybody all together?
And how did you feel about your officers?
Yeah, well, when I was in boot camp, we had black and white.
drill instructors and some Hispanics, quite a few Filipinos and other nationalities that would do their five years military service to get citizenship in the United States.
What did you think of your officers?
I thought they were a real good class of officers.
They were more, a little bit more human than I thought, you know.
They were more sensitive than I had expected.
I mean, like in what sense?
Well, they, they felt for their, their troops a little more than, than I had expected.
I thought they'd just be barking orders all the time instead of trying to get to know you and, and
learn about you and work with you in whatever situation you were in.
So you felt that in your unit... Is the unit that you train with in boot camp the one that you go out to?
No, no.
After boot camp, like I said, you each go into whatever you're inclined, your military occupation.
And then after your specialized school, then we went to...
Jungle Warfare School to prepare for Vietnam.
Where was that at?
It was at Camp Pendleton, California.
And basically what we learned is how to camouflage ourselves to blend in with the countryside and restrict our movements and they'd give us an objective and we'd go and blow it up and learn first aid
and how to care for wounds in the jungle because they get infected right away and all that stuff.
And then we were broken up in groups of, there was 300 of us that flew to Vietnam.
But once you go from here to Okinawa, well, Wake Island was the midpoint.
And then we landed on Okinawa.
We were again split up.
We turned in all our stateside gear and drew jungle equipment.
And then we flew, like I flew from Okinawa to Chu Lai, Vietnam.
That's where I started.
It's about in the second core area.
Mainly I was in the second core and the I core area.
which is the upper northern part of Vietnam.
Oh, so close to the northern border?
Yeah, the last few months I ended up along the DMZ, the Demiller County.
Oh, yeah, okay.
Just a little bit about your training, the jungle warfare.
Did the conditions there in Camp Pendleton, were they the same as when you were out there fighting?
I mean, could you say that, that the jungle that was there in Vietnam was the same as California?
No, no.
No, California is real.
Camp Elton especially is real rocky and hilly, but Vietnam is a dense kind of jungle.
Like in July, for three miles inland, it was nothing but white sand and sparse growth.
And when you got after the three miles in, it became the dense jungle covered mountains and hills.
Nothing over here prepared us, really, for what we were going to go through.
I mean, when you saw the jungle and everything, you said, like, this is not what we were trained for.
All right.
Yeah, it was kind of spooky and eerie, yeah.
But, you know, when you're young, you feel like you can do anything, go through anything.
So the looks of it didn't bother me.
Mainly it was the heat that bothered me, the hot.
Uh-huh.
Because we were hot.
hot and sweaty all the time.
And everything was an effort, you know, when you're under those conditions.
The hot, humid air was thick and musty to breathe and everything.
Okay.
So when did you actually, what date could you give me that you left camp to Vietnam?
It's easier to remember because it was May, about May the 15th.
It was several days before my
20th birthday.
I was 19 years old.
So that was what year?
1965 you went?
Yeah.
Okay.
Alright.
Well, 66 actually.
Yeah.
May of 66.
Okay, that's when you went.
Yeah.
Okay, and when you left, what did you think you were going to do in Vietnam?
I mean, what was the mission and what was the point?
Were you also advising or helping Arvin?
No.
We were already involved in the combat stage.
Well, I knew our mission was mainly to keep the infantry supplied with whatever we could carry, because in this amphibious vehicle, we could carry ammunition, food, troops, everything.
It was like a big cargo carrying type of vehicle.
Okay.
On the way to Vietnam, what kind of plane did you go in, and was it all the men?
What were the men talking about?
What did you all talk about?
Well, there was 300 of us, and we flew over in a C-141.
They call it the Starlifter.
And there was, all the time we were making remarks about the plane, that it looked like, because when we landed on
When we were going to take off from Edwards Air Force Base, it broke.
One of the engines or something.
So we ended up spending an additional two days at Edwards Air Force Base.
And it was mainly an Air Force Base.
And they weren't used to having 300 Marines running around their base.
So we got a lot of comments from the
the dependents there that didn't like having 300 Marines running all over, running wild on their base.

And so when it finally did take off, we were all kind of worried, because usually you are way up in the air and you can see nothing but the Pacific Ocean down below, and it's something like a 10 to 12 hour flight from Edwards to Wake Island.
And so one of the guys says, how does it feel being in
30,000 nuts and bolts flying in close formation.
There was a good sense of humor and camaraderie on the airplane all the time.
Did anybody ever express fear, like, oh, I'm afraid of this, or, you know, if something happens, but don't, you know.
No, a lot of us, you know,
Being in the Marines, you learn your discipline.
You keep your fears hidden to yourself.
You don't show it or make it known.
So once you got to Vietnam, your commanding officers, did you think that they were competent?
I mean, at the beginning, did you think they were?
Were you confident with them?
Yes.
There was a captain in charge of our company.
I thought he was real competent.
And there was this one weird staff sergeant, he was a Filipino.
We didn't have any confidence at all in him.
Why?
Well, he kind of like, he was afraid to die and he slept in a box at night in case the enemy came and overran us.
They wouldn't find him and kill him, so he'd hide himself in a box and sleep in a box at night.
Like a cardboard box or something?
Well, it was a wooden box.
So you're talking about the Filipino officer now?
Well, he was a staff sergeant, and he was only there for about three more months, and I guess he was...
He realized he was getting real close to coming home, and he didn't want anything to happen to him.
So where would he put this cardboard?
Was it a cardboard box he would sleep in?
No, it was like a wooden oblong crate, like a shipping crate.
Yeah.
And he kept it in a tent, because we all lived in tents in those days.
But he really didn't sleep in that crate.
Was he abused by the other officers and by maybe even you all?
I don't know, because he was more like a supply staff sergeant, and we would just go to him when we needed parts to put on our vehicles and stuff.
We didn't have that much to do with him, except at night when we were on beach guard, sometimes he'd be the duty NCO, and he'd have to come and check us to see if we were awake and on duty.
Did he do that well or?
Yeah, yeah, he was real good at it.
Okay, because I was going to say, if he ever gave you an order, was it like, yeah, whatever, or would you really listen to him?
Well, I guess basically we didn't really have to listen to him.
And, oh, go ahead.
Because of the, you know, military discipline and rank and all that stuff, general orders.
Okay, and so your head officer was who, and where, could you tell me about himself?
Was he white or what?
Well, Captain, I think his name was Captain Dittmar, yeah, and he was a white Anglo, I guess what you call an Anglo, and then his executive officer, I don't, I can't remember his name, but he was a,
what was called the top first sergeant.
He was real intelligent because he'd spent 20 years in the reserves already.
And when he got to Vietnam, he knew quite a bit about amphibious operations.
That's what I was in, amphibious operations.
Okay, so when you did get there, your assignment was to help bring in supplies, right?
Keep the infantry supplied with ammunition, food, and water, and also help them secure their perimeter.
Whenever we'd move them deeper into the jungle, we'd use our vehicles to knock down trees,
and clear a field of fire for them in case the enemy attacked them at night.
They would have a clear, open field of fire.
What did they ever told you about the Vietnam people, Vietnamese?
I mean, had they ever said, well, the people are this way.
You need to act this way.
How were you told to treat the people, the citizens of the country?
We were told to treat them with respect and not make fun of their

surroundings or their homes or wherever they lived and to have as little as possible to do with them because our vehicles were highly susceptible to sabotage and we stayed as far away from them as we could so they wouldn't plant a bomb or something on our vehicles.
Was there always a fear that they might have VCE or what was your biggest fear with them?
Yeah, they were mainly pro-Viet Cong, and they would try anything to put us out of commission.
But there's something about Orientals that, like a certain mystique, that I consider them a little weird.
And I don't know, when I used to
look at them and their slanted eyes, you know.
It was just something weird I didn't like about it.
And then their small, wiry frames.
Most of them are small, wiry.
And I just, a certain basic, like a repellent.
They were a little repelling to me.
I couldn't stand them.
Really?
Yeah.
And it was weird to me because I grew up on the east side of town with black people and Polish people.
And I surprised myself that I was feeling a little prejudice toward them, that I didn't like them.
But I figured it was the indoctrination I received in the Marines about killing the Kong.
that these Orientals all looked alike.
So that you could never really distinguish if they were...
Right.
I had already grouped them and classified them because of my training.
And I never could bring myself to lie.
Did you ever go into any of their villages?
Yeah.
Another mission we had was to give them medical aid.
And we'd take this team of doctors into a village, and we'd stop on the outskirt of the village and guard our vehicles while the doctors went in and treated them for whatever.
They treated a lot of infections, ear, nose, throat infections, and there was a lot of malaria and stuff that the doctors would go into a village and treat these people.
So mainly, I think my balance at the time, I started 50% of it was good, and then the other 50% was combat and stuff.
50% good, you mean like helping out the people?
Right, mainly we helped a lot of people.
So when you said you helped, did you just bring the doctors or you helped assist the patients?
Well, if the doctors needed our help, we'd go ahead and help them, but...

mainly like there was three crewmen per vehicle and we always went in teams of two vehicles we just when you had to guard this big 20-foot vehicle about 12 feet high and you know you had to spread out far enough to where you could watch your half of the vehicle the other guy watched the other half of the vehicle and another guy would be inside on the radios
listening for any trouble.
Did anything ever happen?
Were you all ever attacked while you were in a village helping?
Yeah, once in a while we'd get sniper fire.
We'd get inside, close it all up because they were bulletproof to a certain caliber of weapon and the bullets would just bounce off because mainly
Back in those days, the Vietnamese had carbines and small arms.
They didn't drag around anything big or heavy enough to knock us out of action.
And we'd go in the village, get the doctors, and then go on back to our area.
And we'd report what had happened.
There was this one sniper that was operating in our area, they called him
the B.A.R.
kid, and everybody was afraid of him because he carried a Browning automatic rifle.
That's what B.A.R.
stands for.
And he had picked off a lot of people, a lot of Marines, because there was this one point where you come to this river, and there was a ferry.
The Navy operated a ferry there.
And the military, whoever was going to cross there, had to wait for the ferry, and that was when the sniper would

would open up and kill people with his an automatic weapon with a 30 caliber range it has a lot of range and a real flat trajectory so he was really a good shot with it when you said they had the your enemy or whatever had small little carbines and
Did that do anything to you?

Like, you thought, well, they really aren't going to hurt me because they only have these small weapons and we have all this great, I mean, how much, what kind of military weapons did you have compared to them?
And did you think you had more confidence because of what you had than they did?
Yes, I considered our weapons better and more effective than theirs.
But, like, they operated most of the time with the element of surprise in their favor.
Like you never received a big advance warning of a big attack.
Most of the time, we got ambushed, a surprise attack.
So even if they had their small weapons, they had the element of surprise in their favor.
So it was still worrisome to be over there, that constant.
They had to be on constant guard all the time because that's how they did get their advantages by a sneak attack.
So you didn't really underestimate them then, right?
No, never did.
Did you ever have any contact with Arvin?
And if you did, what so?
What were your impressions about Arvin?
The Arvins were, you know, basically afraid and
they were real young men.
Their training wasn't all that good, and they lacked a lot of self-confidence.
I guess because they were there a lot longer than we were all their lives, and they knew what their enemy was capable of.
So there was a lot of cowardice among them, a lot of them.
The way I knew this was our headquarters was right by an ARVN training camp.
And every once in a while, we'd go and take supplies.
Fresh water was hard to come by where we were at.
So we had these big water trailers that we called water buffalos that would hold around 500 gallons of water.
And we'd haul those around.
And our duties were rotated.
Every once in a while, it would be our turn to go and supply the armament
And we'd start talking, because their instructors were the special forces, the green berets.
And they'd be training them.
And they'd tell us, we lost so many Arvin last night, they ran off with their weapons to join the Viet Cong.
So I knew a lot more, because I covered a lot more territory.
And then when we went on operations that we did carry the Arvin,
One time we were going to drop them off to go patrol through this village and they didn't want to get off the vehicle.
They were afraid.
You mean like you stopped and they just wouldn't get off?
Yeah.
How did you get them off?
We pushed them out and kicked them out.
We threatened them and threw them out.
What did you think once they got off?
That they were going to turn around and go home or what?
Well, probably...
They'd probably just go and hide in the jungle and not fulfill their mission.
Did you ever think that they really wanted this war, that they stood behind it?
No, I don't think they wanted the war.
And they'd be willing to swing with whoever was in authority at the time.
They'd go that way.
So they were with you mainly for the foods and the training?
Protection, yeah.
till we got kicked out and the North Vietnamese took over.
What did you think about the Green Berets there?
I thought the Green Berets were real effective and they weren't afraid of any situation they came across because we used to go and pick them up.
They go out on their missions for months
And then they'd radio in where they were at, and we'd go.

Sometimes the only way to get there was by a river, because during the monsoon season when it rained all the time, we were the only ones that could operate helicopters, and planes couldn't fly in dense cloud, rainy type of weather.
So we'd go and pick them up and bring them back from their missions, and we'd talk to them.

And this one group had been out for a month, and whenever they would come across an enemy encampment, they would call in artillery fire or naval gunfire, whatever was available, and destroy that camp, and then pack up and run and hide.
Because once the fire was called in on the enemy, they'd start looking for whoever was calling in the fire on them.
And we would talk a lot with them.
I thought they were doing a real good job, real effective.
Did you ever have any chance or did you ever want to be a part of the Green Berets?
No, not really.
I was mainly content with being in the Marines.
And we also worked with the toughest unit in the Marines is the recon.
What is it?
They're reconnaissance.
They do almost everything.
The same thing as the Green Berets did.
They go out in the jungle and find enemy encampments.
And they decide what kind of harassment they're going to do to that enemy.
Either they call in artillery fire, naval gunfire, or aircraft.
Or else they hide real far away and just shoot one of them to demoralize the others.
You know, they'd stay hidden and then pick another one off and have a shocking effect on the others.
To where they'd eventually, like, retreat or... Yeah, they'd get demoralized and wouldn't want to organize an attack against us.
Um,

When you were there and all these missions you went on, did you ever feel like there was a certain point you were going, you know, like a linear warfare, like your objective was to get up to that border and push them all the way back or what?
No, we never had that kind of an objective.
It was just what they consisted of.
Yeah, it was, you'd take a hill one day and then you'd get orders to move on to somewhere else and forget about that area.
Do you ever think, what's the point?
Yeah, it got kind of, we all started wondering when the politicians were going to make up their mind to go ahead and win it, because it was like a cat and mouse game we were carrying on over.
When you say the politicians and winning it, what did winning it mean?
The politicians would do what?
Agree to do what?
Give us the orders to go ahead and invade North Vietnam and put them out of action and bring them under military control, our control.
So what did, I don't understand because you feel that, did you feel you had the manpower and the equipment and everything to go ahead and invade North Vietnam and do away with it?
Yes, when I was over there,
We were, we had just built, this was the biggest air base in Southeast Asia.
It was, had been built in July.
It was a big landing strip for airplanes.
And at night we would guard them.
And then I remember when LBJ or Lyndon Baines Johnson, he started, he ordered the first bombing of the North, Vietnam.
All day and night for a week, planes were landing, loading up, and taking off.
I had never seen so many airplanes in my whole life getting fully loaded with bombs and everything and taking off.
And this was 15, 20 minutes apart for a whole week, landing and taking off, landing and taking off.
Like for 24 hours a day, this is?
Yeah.
I had never experienced that.
I didn't even think we had that much air power.
Why did he do that?
Why did you think LBJ did that?
To try and make them, bring them to their knees, make them give up, to break the will of the people.
And did it to you, or what happened?
No, it just made them madder, made them try harder.
They dug tunnels and moved everything underground to get away from the bombs.
Do you think that in any way that this bombing hit innocent people that weren't involved and got them turned against the U.S.?

Yeah, I'm sure it did, because every so often in my past experiences, I've talked with pilots that were over there in Vietnam, and they'd say when they were going to make a bombing run, they would shoot these missiles at them, so they'd
speed up and outrun the missiles, well, where's the missile going to go when it runs out of fuel?
Back to the ground and blow up the same people that fired it at them.
So not only were we bombing them and hurting their people, but the same weapons they used on us when they ran out of fuel would have to hit the ground again and explode or detonate.
Did you ever know of any instances where the aircraft may have hit
U.S. forces?
Do you ever remember anything like that?

Yeah, a lot of Marines that were wounded over there, when I was at Camp Pendleton, they would tell us that sometimes the fighting would get so fierce that they'd have to call in artillery fire right on their own position or aircraft.
This one guy was telling me they were
fighting this North Vietnamese Army unit.
And they called in for aircraft support.
And this F4 was coming to help him.
And he said that he didn't want to shoot because there was a lot of air turbulence.
It was real windy that day, up in the high upper altitude.
And they said, we don't give a heck where you hit.
Just open up, shoot.
And he ended up shooting five of his own fellow Marines.
because of the air turbulence.
A plane shakes a lot like that when there's air turbulence.
How did that affect the men and the morale?
Well, they were so besieged by this North Vietnamese army unit that they didn't care.
It was either lose some of them, or this army unit would massacre all of them.
So they'd rather sacrifice a few so that some of them would live.
Can you describe what type of warfare you were involved in and different examples of your combat missions?
Mainly what most of the fighting we did was at night on river patrols and beach guard.
At night we would spread a whole platoon of tractors along the beach, say about 100 yards apart, and our mission was

because the Vietnamese would fish every night off the coast and they had orders to keep one light aft and to stay not to come any closer than 500 yards to the beach or else we had orders to sink them because they were suspected of sneaking in weapons and explosives and stuff.
So we'd spend the night watching them, and every once in a while, we'd get sniper fire from behind us.
So we'd turn around and start some, every other tractor would turn around and start firing inland while the opposite was still watching the beach.
So one night we were firing away, and we started getting even heavier fire back.
So we got on the radios, and we found out that there was an infantry unit
And we were hitting them with our fire.
You mean it was the U.S.?
Well, it was another Marine unit.

And what had happened, this sniper had gotten between us, and the sniper would shoot at us, so he would draw our fire, and he knew that all our straight bullets were going to be hitting into that Marine base.
Well, there are lots of examples of this.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah, it happened quite a bit.
Especially at night, and the range of our weapons, machine guns, some Marines would just spray, shoot, and not aim at any particular target.
And why was night warfare better than day?

I didn't say it was better, but mainly those were the kind of missions we were stuck with because the enemy, all the enemy movements were at night because, you know, our airplanes couldn't find them and they felt safer under the cover of darkness.
They could move a lot more heavy equipment.
And then we had to patrol rivers at night that we thought the enemy was using to, to
float cargo and ammunition.
Because you could move faster on a river than through the jungle carrying stuff.
But most of my missions were at night.
The missions we did get during the day, we would move an infantry company deeper into the jungle or supply them with ammunition.
Sometimes we'd be loaded with nothing but mortar shells, explosives.
And then we'd be target, we could draw sniper fire from a lot further off because these huge amphibs could be seen miles away.
And then the noise of our engines would give us away too.
Were you ever in any hand-to-hand combat or could you ever like see the VC or who would you say, I mean how would you call your enemy?
What did you call them?
Usually VC or?
Yeah.
What names did you call them?
The Viet Cong or Charlie, stuff like that.
Or sometimes we called them, uh, uh, gooks.
Yeah, a couple of times they were close enough to where we threw grenades at them.
One time they were trying to sneak up on us.
And we threw grenades and killed three of them.
But it was very rare we got that close to them.
Mainly, we'd shoot them pretty far off with machine guns and stuff.
And then there was this one village.
We were with this infantry company on this hill, and you could see down at this river valley and a village.
And the infantry company, there was a little island in the middle of this river, and it was called Shark Island.
because the ocean over here and every once in a while some sharks would come up that river.
There was a lot of sharks in the China Sea and that's why they call it Shark Island because from that island every so often you'd see a shark.
Well when the fishing boats were going out from that village they'd have to stop by that island and there was Marines there checking their IDs
to make sure that the Viet Cong didn't sneak back and infiltrate.
And then about 1 o'clock in the morning, they'd send a patrol in through that village to look and to make sure that Viet Cong weren't infiltrating or getting ready to mount an assault.
And we'd be guarding our vehicles because the infantry, a lot of times, they would kind of like disown us.
They said Amtraks, keep your vehicles away.
If a shell hits it, it's going to blow up like a giant bomb and kill.
So we'd have to be away from the infantry in our own little area.
And we'd have to set up our own guard and take turns at night.
And there's one particular night, this infantry patrol that went into that village, they started getting shot at real bad.
a Viet Cong force, we didn't know how many in that village.
And when they came up on them, so they were getting shot at pretty bad.
And they called in for air support and these helicopters came and started
You could see the machine gun fire like a red line just outlining the whole village.
And the infantry was right in the middle of it.
So they thought they had had it, and they started burning the whole village down and killing everybody.
And it wasn't a pretty sight the next day.
What did y'all have to do, go through it?
Yeah, we had to go in there and get the bodies out.
And whoever was left alive, we had to get them, you know, medical aid and stuff.
It was pretty bad.
Was it always just firing?
I mean, what about napalm or any of those defoliants?
Well, whenever there was a big, yeah, there was a lot of defoilant sprayed all around us.

that Agent Orange, there was a, we were involved in a lot of experimental stuff too, like they were developing these smart bombs, and when they moved us up to the, just below the DMC, there was a bridge over this big river, it was called Nammo Bridge, and the Air Force was experimenting with these smart bombs.
Those are those bombs that detect things?
Yeah.

Like one airplane will drop or they'll plant a transmitter on a bridge that they want to blow up, and this plane will come over and drop this bomb, and it locks in on that signal, and it will destroy that bridge.
Well, they had picked this bridge to experiment on, and we were guarding it.
And they dropped this one of those smart bombs.
We could see it with a parachute coming down.
And, you know, they didn't tell us everything about the experiment.
But it blew over on the enemy, in deep enemy territory.
And we had to go and get it back at all costs.
Why did you have to get the bomb back?
Because there was certain data inside of it that the Air Force wanted.
So they could keep working on that bomb and in
perfecting it or improving it.
And we lost quite a few guys trying to get it back.
You all did get it though?
Yeah, we got it back.
So when it went down, it was shot to mess up this bridge, right?
But then you had a, what data?
Well, it was like a dummy just gathering data.
You know, I couldn't tell you exactly what it was, but...
